Understate: The expert's verdict suggests that the claim may understate the job growth in New Jersey by using a slightly lower number (143,000) instead of the actual gain of 142,400 jobs.
Lack enough support: The expert mentions that the methodology used to measure the job gains may not be ideal, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. This suggests that the claim lacks enough support in terms of the measurement used.
Problematic assumption: The expert points out that the timeframe chosen by Christie (February 2010 to August 2013) may not be the best way to evaluate employment trends. This indicates a problematic assumption in the claim.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert mentions that it is best to review seasonally adjusted, year-over-year data to evaluate employment trends accurately. By using a different timeframe, Christie's claim may have an alternative explanation for the job growth in New Jersey.
